description:
Wow, beautiful views. And I had a wonderful day with my family.
The weather was good and we also could ride a bike.
I love this place.
Don't hesitate any more, come to have a relaxed day!
author: Geneva W.

description:
I walked through this little beach front property as I was walking to Pier 39 from Ghirardelli Square. From here, I took a few photos of the Ghirardelli building. Facing the bay, you can sit in the stadium like seating to blissfully watch the beach goers, take in the crisp air, and people watch. It has a great view of the bay and the GGB. Although, the bridge is pretty far and photos of the bridge will look like it's so far away in the horizon.

Otherwise, as a tourist, I pretty much breezed through this park with taking a few pictures here in there.
author: Antonio L.

description:
Picturesque spot to walk off dinner before the temperature drops. Concrete bleachers for sitting, waves for watching, small strip of sand for drawing, building, or running from waves. 

I like jealously watching the occasional wet-suited swimmers swim back and forth in the distance. 

The waves tempted my offspring so we had to bathe the kid after we got home. Despite the chill, he loved it. I did not love vacuuming my car afterward but that's the cost of happiness, I guess.
author: Loli L.

description: I took an Uber here excited to have a hot cocoa and finish up some emails. Long story short, I walked down to sit on the steps overlooking the water. Shortly after, two guys came running up behind me and grabbed my purse. Thank God for multiple strangers that helped me chase them down and I got my bag back but PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE be on high alert and don't let your guard down for one second. It was terrifying and shook me to my core. Don't let this review dishearten you from visiting, just be smart and know your surroundings. It was a beautiful view of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate bridge, it felt very safe and well populated. It was during broad daylight that this happened. Keep your eyes and ears peeled at all times.
author: Maria B.

description: Nestled in front of Ghirardelli, a less frequented (but sometimes windy) park not as busy but with great views and lush greens.
author: Kimberly H.

description: This is such a lovely park, the views are great, and the place is just beautiful. There are public restrooms, lots of places to eat or grab a snack nearby. It almost feels like you are in a forest if you get the top of the hill. It gets crowded on weekends during the day, and despite clear marking, watch out for bicycles.  There are a number of bicycle renting facilities in the area, and sometimes out of town bicycles riders can veer onto pedestrian paths. That's hardly the park's fault though, perhaps companies who rent bikes should explain it more clearly. Overall, one of my favorite spots in t
author: Lucy G. K.

description:
Aquatic Park is a great place to get in an open water swim and then grab a bite in the area afterwards.

Pros:
-Protected cove w a buoy line and lots of other landmarks to use for navigation/sighting.  

-Relatively clean...it IS the bay, so you're not going to get pristine waters with 70 ft visibility (go to Tahoe for that - it's totally worth it!), but the beach is pretty clean, there aren't usually visible trash or pollutants in the water and the bottom isn't full of slimy weeds in the shallow area.

-Parking before 10 is easy.  Admittedly later than that, it can get challenging.  In desperation, there are parking structures very nearby.

-There are several post swim options nearby in Ghiradelli Square for brunch, hot chocolate etc.

-It's never all that crowded in the water, even if there is a race from Alcatraz or the like going on.

-You really can't beat it on a warm sunny day--the bay looks gorgeous and Alcatraz and the Marin headlands are a great backdrop for swimming.

Cons:
-When the parking is difficult, it contributes to people sharking for spots.  I'm never a huge fan of being stared at by someone waiting for my spot while I basically get naked in public.

-If you're not a dolphin club member, there really aren't any facilities for you to use like at a lot of public beaches.  But, never fear, you'll get good at changing in the parking lot at your car.  

-It's cold, but not bad if you're prepared.  Some brave souls swim without wetsuits, but a full wetsuit, silicone cap and goggles and you'll warm up after about 5 minutes of swimming.

-Two sea lions live in the cove.  Most of the time they stick themselves and hang out on the west side; occasionally they like to join the swimmers in the buoy line. While some may view them as a pro, I like to keep my distance in the water...they seem a lot bigger and less friendly when you're face to face with them in their living room.  I'll admit, they are pretty cute--especially from shore.
author: Sara E.

description:
I love this park is really huge go walk around get your exercise you can see the beach you can see the bridge people swimming it gets cold here so bring a jacket.
Can take great pictures the turnaround cable car is here at the beginning of the park. Do have a lot of benches where you can sit down just enjoy if the Sun is out and get a suntan. 
But be advised there are few homeless people that walk around and come up to you and ask for money or food so just be careful of your surroundings.
author: Lizzie G.

description:
Whenever I'm in the city and want to swim, this is my go to place! It's a great place for open water swimming for all levels. The water is usually calm and relaxing. There are 5 buoys parallel to the beach and what I have been told is that 3 loops equal a mile. Swimmers go either direction and mind their own business. 

Besides swimming, on weekends you may see groups of people exercising on the bleachers. Cyclists,  runners/walkers and tourists pass through the area frequently, as the wharf is not so far away. 

Across the street is Ghirardelli square. So after a nice swim you can have instant gratification by ordering a sundae or some hot chocolate. Oh yeah! 

Public bathrooms are not far since its on the other side of the museum but if your heading for some dessert, there are restrooms also located in Ghirardelli Square. Parking maybe a challenge on weekends. Van Ness street gets pretty packed quickly since its free for 4 hours or else there is metered parking for .25cents per half hour.. Not bad considering your in SF.
author: Anne P.

description:
Aquatic park is at the foot of Polk Street on the Bay.
With a fantastic view of Alcatraz and Hyde St. Pier it hardens to the historic periods that existed here.
In the morning what a great place to start the day with the sound of the tide, the wind blowing and the stunning view of the Bay.
Locals and tourists frequent the Park & it's an inspiring place to be.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Just like all other open water swimmers, this is my regular spot for training for my Alcatraz crossings.  It has a barrier wall that keeps the big waves out .  Though, I did spot a sea lion today on my way walking there. I must say it looked very cute when I was on land watching,  however it gave me a few goose bumps when I encountered it in the water.  Often times, sea lions leave you alone. So this was my first encounter after many years of training in the bay.

Other than sea lions, there's no other problem. Swimmers are nice, pleasant and courteous.  Everyone minds their own business unless you want to start a conversation with them. 

One tip: use a wetsuit if you have no experience swimming in the bay. The water can be cold.  If you indeed want to swim without a wetsuit, make sure you understand that your body will need a little time to adjust to the cold temperature.  Don't stay in the water without a wetsuit for more than 20 minutes on your first swim, you will get hyperthermia.  I've seen someone get hyperthermia during my training a few years ago.  It can be life threatening so stay safe.
author: M P.

description: First Mongo see two crazy people swimming in water!!! What? Mongo confused. Waaaaaaayyyyy toooooooo cold for swimming!!!!! Mongo no like cold. Make Mongo shiver. But then Mongo see many not-crazy people walking every where. And jogging. And bicycle people. Mongo see San Fran-Sis-Ko Bridge. And many, many little boats. And Mongo see big old boat. And Mongo aks-si-dent-lee take picture of Mongo's finger - AGAIN!. And Mongo see Alcatraz. And Mongo see other old boats over there. Then Mongo go look for the old boats over there...
author: Mongo I.

description:
I was in the area and looked for a place to walk and unwind, without all that jazz of Fisherman's Wharf. Aquatic Park to the rescue! 

There's a beach where people swim in every given water temperature, a large square-like seating area, and a looong pier.

Yes, the pier. It really helps you to unwind. Walk to the end of it and get a fantastic view of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Fisherman's Wharf, and the San Francisco skyline. 

I do get why some Yelpers complain about the cleanliness but it's a city park after all. I tolerate.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Great family environment, can buy points per rides, easy access and parking. Nice weather in the afternoon evening. Direct access to the beach.
author: Carmen M.

description:
Fleet Week in San Francisco is truly a great time: we get to honor and interact with the naval staff who work so hard for our country, visit the ships, but we all know that the stars of the show are the awesome Blue Angels.

Once a year, the blue skies are interrupted with the roaring of these powerful jets. The squadron flies the Boeing F/A-18 Hornet and the Lockheed Martin C-130 Hercules. (Fat Albert!) Seeing these in action, being around aviation enthusiasts and photography fans while taking in the gorgeous views of San Francisco bay and Alcatraz make for a spectacular Sunday. 

And there's no other place to do it than Aquatic Park.

5 "I love San Francisco" Stars!!!
author: Janice C.

description:
While the beach part of this park is not as large or memorable as some of the other ones around SF, what makes this area spectacular are the sights from the coast and the overall casual tranquility it exudes. The coast is perfect for children to play around as well as visit the Maritime Museum, and there are plenty of people biking and going for a nice stroll no matter the weather.

So if you're in the Marina and want to get away from the crowded touristy areas of the Wharf, Ghirardelli Square and Fort Mason, just walk downhill into this somewhat secluded cove and just sit on the banks for a great view of Hyde Street Pier, or dip your feet in the refreshing water. And if you're up for it, walk all the way down Aquatic Park Pier for a better view of Alcatraz!
author: Kyrie S.

description:
So pretty but sooooo cold!

Parking for a Saturday night wasn't bad. We actually found a spot or two that weren't too far from the entrance.

Not sure if I should call this a dock but I feel like I want to call it that so here it goes. The dock was 1/3 gated off because you can see that the sea breeze was eating away at the metal on the dock. The walk all the way to the end wasn't bad. It was windy but that's how it is whenever you are near the water, so it was expected.

The view as you're walking towards the end of the dock was gorgeous. You could get a perfect shot of Ghirardelli square on one side & a close view of Alcatraz on the other. 

There were a lot of "Watch for Swimmers" signs, come to find out, this is where the Polar Bear Club meets & swims. That is crayyy because it was sooooo cold! I can't imagine even putting my feet in the water, let alone swimming in it (Oh, I can't swim fyi) 

They had benches for people to sit that had high backs to shield you from some of the wind, I'm guessing. 

Walking back towards the shore, there is a man-made beach that has a little 2-3 stairway to step down to the sand. There was also what looked like stadium seating to watch a boat show. It's pretty cool. People were watching the sunset while sitting on it.

From there it's a straight shot to Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39.
author: Camille C.

description:
Jumpy Jump Ocean. "Daddy, let's go back to the beach," he says, "we can run freely on the warm sand, build sculptures and swim in the refreshing ocean." My son and I. The best connection ever. I adore the privilege of being a parent. Too much love never spoils children. Children become spoiled when we substitute presents for presence. Oceanic play-crafted with pride at San Francisco's iconic Aquatic park. 

A vast lion
with strong feelings
on west coast
fresh, monied, 
handsome, healthy
exuberant, extrovert, 
third generation only child
a peaceful rebel

An ocean rumbles
where sharks can be found
every wave must be earned
possibilities of perfection
cornerstone of society
surrounded with love
as the stars and galaxies
that rest above

A dog barks
to a false witness
most things in life change
some don't
someone is either friendly or enemy
their road mirrors the ocean
our road never really ends
endless play
living in abundance
no trespassing.
author: Saurabh S.

description: Great place to get in some open water swimming in a protected area of SF Bay. Water is really clean but extremely cold so come prepared! I wore a full wet suit, neoprene cap, and booties. Took about 5 minutes of swimming before the sting in my face and fingers went away!
author: Lou M.

description:
Nice urban park with a small sliver of sand beach. Signs are posted that pets are not allowed on the beach, but I saw a number of dogs on the beach anyway. The views here are awesome. The Golden Gate bridge is on one side of you visual horizon and Alcatraz is on the other side of your visual horizon. In between, container ships roll in every few minutes, swimmers do laps the length of the beach, sailboats glide by in the distance, parasails can be seen further down the beach.
We were there so that my 3 year old grandson and 5 year old granddaughter could run off some excess energy. We had brought some beach toys with us. They had a blast running along the beach, building sand castles, and filling the toy dump truck up with sand and pushing it along the beach. TIP: The adjacent Hyde pier has an outside sand rinse-off station just outside of the bathrooms.
It is very windy and cool here, so bring a sweater or windbreaker along with your sunscreen and drinking water and have a great time.
author: Sue C.

description:
Open water swim treasure! Looking for a different venue for my tri training (usually train at Shadow Cliffs in Pleasanton) This was magnificent! I loved it! It's unbelievably scenic and truly exhilarating( i went on a Saturday morning about 8 AM. There was a wonderful amount of swimmers out there, and I just loved it. 

There is free four hour parking at the very end of Van Ness Ave. One downside, is that before 10 AM there were no open restrooms, and I really wanted to change out of my wet stuff afterwards. I finally went behind everything up to Ghirardelli Square, followed the orange signs until I found the rest room deep in the bowels of Ghirardelli Square. 

That said, the swim itself was magnificent! There were buoys you can swing back-and-forth for a sixth of a mile each way, or you can go around the perimeter I have heard it said somewhere from three quarters of a mile to a mile. The swimmers these know the deal and they're happy to tell you.

It's nice, because it is cold, ocean, saltwater, but really no waves. This is especially plus for beginning open water swimmers. It's like a step between the lake, and the ocean. I was so excited and I can't wait to go again. There are terrific scenic hiking trails and lots of great cycling there too, if you want to do some bricks.

The only concern I had was where to leave my car key. I got lucky, because there was a little tri club starting off there and they had no problem letting me leave my gear there under their watchful eyes. Other people do things like leave everything in their car, and set their key on top of the tire wheel. Actually, from this point I decided to buy a little open water swim buoy, which trails behind you, and hold your keys too. That would have made the whole thing complete.

Don't neglect this excellent spot for open water swimming! If you want to spend some money, I've heard you can pay $10 for day use for the swim club at the far end after 11am which has showers and a steam room, but I wanted to go cheap, and early!
author: Martha S.

description:
Awesome little beach area right next to Ghirardelli Square! Spent time here following the chocolate festival, and would go back- calm little area with a bunch of free grass to lay on or amphitheater style seating to watch the water, in addition to a few rows of seating down in the sand. Saw a few seals in the water- they actually came pretty close to shore!
Close to many restaurants and bars (albeit overpriced touristy ones), which is convenient for meeting up with friends.
author: Stefany V.

description: Take the time and rent a bike or take a walk through here. Beautiful views and a variety of stores a long the way. Bike rentals weren't expensive at all and they have their own path to follow.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I heard there are free group open water swims in the bay. Does anyone have any details about this, when and where they meet?
Thanks!
author: Neil S.

description: We didn't walk to the way end of the pier as I had planned on doing. As we walked a bit down it it seemed that going further wouldn't produce much better of a view. You can get a good view of SF, the famous chocolate sign, and the GGB just from going halfway around. You can also bike it and there are a good number of bike rental places in the immediate area. This is the only location in the city where there is still beach - as in sand. At the time we walked by there was a group of people racing homemade (I.e., cardboard) boats which was fun to stop and see. On a nice day there is a large section of cement steps so you could come and sit and read or something. There is a grassy park nearby too which had a good number of people sprawled out in it.
author: Ben S.

description: Excellent photography can be taken here. Lots of landmarks to take photos and people watch. Close to Ghirardelli Sq. Take a jacket can be a bit chilly near the water.
author: Lisa F.

description:
June 22, 2014 

Quick story from my swim today:

Jumped in for a swim around 10:30am. It was a great day to swim since the water was not cold at all. It felt like I could have just swum in my jammers. It was a sunny morning and the waters temperature felt like the one of local pools at Sava, Balboa, etc. I did about 2 turn arounds from one end to the last buoy  by the docks. I continued swimming until I saw something floating conspicuously in front of me. I thought to myself that it was just another swimmer, but I was curious so as I got maybe 20 feet away from it, I removed my tinted goggles and saw that it was a SEA LION!!!! I was super ecstatic! It was like seeing a bear in Yosemite! The sea lion was about my size and had pretty long whiskers. Although I was pretty stoked, I started feeling paranoid thinking that maybe a shark or maybe the sea lion might try to bite me, so I continued swimming cautiously, stayed closer to the shore and swam further to the right of it. After swimming a few yards contemplating whether I should continue swimming, I finally decided to swim back to shore, even though there were still many other swimmers there too. I was too paranoid and I wanted to make it to the Summerthing Alice Radio concert anyway haha. I love swimming here and got nothing but respect for the sea lions and their home :D 

This is the best place to train oneself in getting used to the choppy and cold waters for Escape From Alcatraz (which I will one day be competing in) or Orca Alcatraz Challenge (I am attempting on August). 

Enjoy the beautiful area!
Jay Ray
author: Jray M.

description:
Another great place to enjoy the outdoors in SF!  Great views and people do actually swim there.
Not me--brrr!
author: Thomas D.

description:
The beauty of returning to your childhood home is magnified when you return with your own children and basically do a highlight reel of places from some of your favorite childhood memories. San Francisco is one of the world's great cities and one I wish I explored more during the first 25 years of my life when I lived just across the bay.

So on every visit back to visit family and friends, we do some of the things we never bothered to do as locals as well as return to some of our old favorites. And you never know which place will resonate with your own child and become one of their magical memories.

One of my favorites from this trip will be our time at Aquatic Park. After our nice (relatively formal) dinner at McCormick & Kuleto's it was the perfect place to let the boys burn off some steam. We brought a football, so the boys kicked off their shoes, rolled up their pants and played touch football on the beach at sunset with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background. It really doesn't get any better than this.
author: Jen K.

description:
Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful!!!  I swam aquatic park all last summer getting ready for my Alcatraz swim.  C-c-cold in spring, gets better by the end of the summer.  I just swam there last weekend (1st week in March) and it was about 52 degrees.  For those who don't wear a wetsuit like me, it's pretty cold, but bearable.  It's an experience unlike any other.  If you are a swimmer, you must have this experience.  If you swim out to the opening, you have a view of the city, gg bridge, bay bridge and alcatraz, unlike anywhere else in San Francisco.  If you are lucky, a few sea lions will pop their heads up near you :)

Quick tip:  Hit up the Buena Vista for Irish Coffees after your swim!  Warms you right up!
author: Chris C.

description: One of the best open watering swimming spots around and a cool place for tourists just a stones throw from Ghirardelli. Parking is free just west of the park and there are tons of swimmers out on the weekends. Come join the fun!
author: Brian H.

description: Little piece of swimmers heaven! Whether you want to swim the protected cove, row a boat, sail or SUP this is the spot to do it. Very chill park with amazing city views. Sit in the bleachers, stroll the pier, have a Irish coffee at Buena Vista, watch for seals or panhandle for change, this park has it all.
author: Cec D.

description:
The Aquatic Park was nice.

Arrived here around 5:45 am so I got to see the sun come out on a clear day. It was of course chilly, but as the sun came out became pretty warm. When my family and I first arrived, there were very few runners, bikers and walkers however as the time flew by more and more people came out.

I was here to watch some people swim from Alcatraz back to the Aquatic Park, which reminded me of seeing other swimmers + wearing their wet suit. I could only imagine it's very cold in the ocean. lol

Not a frequent visitor to the city however I had forgotten the dangers of homeless people. I wanted to sit on the bleachers closets to the Museum however I saw movement coming from this green colored sleeping bag, corner of my eyes so I bolted out of there. lol Then, I discovered more bleachers, which if you looked behind was Girardelli shop center so we sat over there when out of nowhere this one homeless guy came walking up/down the bleachers obviously talking to himself about Satan + evil + how they are out there and the dangers. He found someone's trash making it a sweet treasure for him as he finished someone's wine cooler. I actually felt sad for him. He came to our world just like any of us had as babies from our mother's womb and to have a life like that guy must be very difficult. 

Overall, Aquatic Park had a beautiful scenery and popular place for runners, bikers, walkers, swimmers, tourist, etc. 

Depending on weather, I got to see Alcatraz + Golden Gate Bridge very clearly + awesome weather today!!

Definitely be back.
author: Risa S.

description:
I love this place!!! My favorite place to practice open water swimming!  It's ocean temperature, but without waves, and generally little, if any, current.  Beach entry/exit, although it can be muddy and rocky depending on where you enter and exit.

Although there are several sailboats anchored here, I've never seen anything moving other than stand up paddle boards and safety escort boats for Alcatraz swims.

Don't expect the public showers to work, and if they do, it's just a dribble.
author: Menlo K.

description: Very beautiful park. Its not a beach but it does have sand to sit down if you so choose. Fisherman's wharf is down the street so your close to food, shopping, and transportation. It can get very chilly as with the rest of the city so keep a jacket handy.
author: Tj J.

description:
I come to Aquatic Park when I'm in the Ghirardelli square area. In particular, I like to walk the end of the Hyde Street Pier and maybe take a walk on the Beach. And with yet another unique view of Golden Gate Bridge and the associated waterfront, I am truly blessed to live in the Bay Area. 

You'll also find the San Francisco Maritime Museum in a Streamline Moderne (late Art Deco) building. The building was originally built (starting in 1936) by the WPA as a public bathhouse, and its interior is decorated with fantastic and colorful murals. The Steamship Room illustrates the technological evolution of maritime power from wind to steam, while the second floor displays include photomurals of the early San Francisco waterfront, lithographic stones, scrimshaw and whaling guns. The third floor gallery is used for visiting exhibitions. 

This cool area is sometimes forgotten among the tourist hordes around the nearby Fisherman's wharf. And if you're doing the long walk along the water, it's a very worthwhile stop before you head up and through Fort Mason and onwards to Marina Green and Crissy Field.
author: Eric B.

description:
My brother&his friends&my coach swam here in preparation for their Alcatraz swim. I told them they couldn't pay me enough to get in. :P They said it wasn't too bad, but.. I definitely prefer my pools. Stuck my feet in and ran away to chill on the sand with my friends.

Overall, it's really nice. Right next to Ghirardelli, and close to a Starbucks [because it gets chilly out there!]. Got hollered at by some drunk guys though [...in the middle of the day]. That was unpleasant.

But generally, it's a nice little strip of beach, and it's great to practice open water in. The waves aren't big at all [thanks to the pier], but the water is coldddddd, so come prepared! I hear Vaseline helps, but it's annoying to get off [if you don't have a wet suit]. Or you could just man up and swim without Vaseline or a wet suit. Orrrrr if you're like me, you could just walk along the sand and enjoy the view on a nice day in the City. You know. Up to you. :P
author: Amy L.

description:
Did my first open water swim in Northern California here this morning! What a rush! A brisk 54 degrees but what a wonderful start to the day.

Will definitely be coming back here! Great way to get introduced to swimming in the bay.

:)
author: Ali B.

description: Lovely area, with or without fog (but especially without!) lots of families and tourists. There's a lot around too, such as food close by etc.
author: Shira S.

description:
1. Go to Ghirardelli Square
2. Order a sea-salted mocha (sm: $4.25, lrg $4.75 splurge for the large, extra hot)
3. Walk to Aquatic Park
4. Find a place to sit
5. Sit
6. People watch

I find this a great people watching place -- all kinds of different people cross this path everyday. All of those people put on a great show. This is a great place for conversational dates. It's beautiful on a summer/fall day, just don't forget to pack a sweater, and enjoy your mocha!
author: Nicole P.

description:
The neighborhood is getting from bad to worst. Before when the economy was decent, the place was fairly maintained. Now the only thing that is done is dumping of the garbage. 

The pier is falling apart literally. The streets are getting dirty from the people who park here all day and use the streets and people who dump their food containers all around. 

Skateboarder and bicyclist rule the area around the pier and police do nothing about it.
author: M C.

description: A nice, peaceful park found right past Pier 39. Ghirardelli Square is located right down the street, and there are a ton of shipping options found all around the park. The beach is also a few feet a way.
author: Brian A.

description:
This is another nice recent discovery of a place to go exercising after work.  Also, one can catch a nice bay view either from the pier extending from the end of Van Ness Ave or from sitting at the amphitheater setting.

In fact, I realize this is a great place to park and then walk to Fisherman's Wharf for dinner.  It's definitely a nice walk along the trail leading from the end of Van Ness Ave going to Jefferson Street.  It's not too hard to find free parking along here during the early evening hours.
author: H K.

description:
Aquatic Park along Beach & Hyde is a great place to watch the boats, calm waters, or get views of places such as the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, North Bay, or Alcatraz during the daytime. On certain nights, the nighttime features the sounds of calm water, lit up lights along the Golden Gate, North Bay, and Alcatraz, though it might be fairly cold for non-natives most of the time.

This place can also be a good spot for swimmers, as the water is pretty cold, but bearable. The swim provides even more spectacular views, plus you might encounter sea lions, though it is up to you if you wish to swim with or pet them.

The easiest way to get here is to drive all the way down north end of Van Ness street, though it depends where you start. This park is also within walking distance of the tourist areas near Fisherman's Wharf. Overall, a nice and peaceful place to take people, day or night, depending on the weather of course.
author: Rob L.

description: Come relax on the beach and watch the Dolphin Club swimmers do laps.  Enjoy the sunset over the Golden gate.  Grab the cable trolley right up the hill.  There is a lot of improvements happening on the street that runs up to the park, will be a great outdoor pedestrian place once completed.
author: Robert P.

description: Had a huge picnic with 50+ people in celebration of 2 friends 30th birthdays and it was the perfect spot! The scenery was so picturesque and the view of the shore and boats was so great.
author: Maria M.

description: This place is a touristy place that's nice to walk around and faffe about. If you like boats and such you'd prolly like this more, but I prefer other parts of the city. Although you can watch Asians do their selfie stick thing I spose (dammit I need one).
author: Xue H.

description:
This was the best place to catch Fleet Week.
There are concrete steps for people to sit on (mind the bird poop) which made it more of a spectator feel as opposed to a bunch of randomly spread people.

The view from this location is great, you have the GG bridge (when looking out) to your left and Alcatraz and Hyde Street Pier to your right.

This is also a place for people to do some laps if you are so inclined.
author: Nick L.

description: Its a nice open setting with close access to Ghiradhelli square, the Hyde Street pier as well as pier 39.
author: Joe E.

description:
Despite being in the middle of Maritime Museum's much needed face lift, AP, you are still worth a nice stroll along the Bay.  

I frequented the park as a child with my family, eating at a long gone snack shack, fishing for nothing along the wooden piers, playing in the bits of sand along the beach, and running up and down the stadium seating.  It's fun to people watch, including the crazy swimmers who brave the water (for being icy cold and incredibly dirty) and just being thankful for water access and some of the most beautiful views.  

Amongst the debris and construction signs, this park will rise once again.
Watch out for those sea gulls now.

PS  Even though we took transit, we saw beaucoup free parking spots-on a non-event Sunday am.
author: Jen L.

description:
Aquatic Park...LOVE!

Parking at AP - There are several 4 hour parking in the area that I know of.  On Jefferson and Hyde (in front of the South End and Dolphin clubs), up Polk and Beach and the end of Van Ness.

Fun at AP - I have taken my kids here several times to enjoy the beach and the water.  Or go chill on the grass and people watch.  Plenty of couples, kids and families come down here to have fun.  And what bonus since Fisherman's Wharf or Ghirardelli Square is close by.

Be active at AP - The runners, the cyclist and the swimmers.  Or the walkers, strollers and sightseers.  If you can work out with great views, why not?  And kudos to those who swim here.  Most are just the nicest people out there.

Fireworks at AP - Best seat ever!!!
author: Pam S.

description: I love walking through Fort Mason and dropping down into Aquatic Park.  I have had my fair share of marine encounters here.  More often than not, a marine mammal head that pops up in Aquatic Park is a sea lion, but the occasional harbor seal is not out of the question.  Mostly, I enjoy looking out at the bay, identifying the various critters and water fowl, and watching the swimmers do laps in the frigid bay.  Those swimmers amaze me.  I can barely dip my toe in the bay let alone my whole body.  They are the royalty of Aquatic Park, and I definitely tip my hat to them, usually as I am walking by quickly wondering where I will get my next hot beverage fix.
author: Danni D.

description: This is one of our favorite places to visit when in SF for the day or a weekend.  Grab some food from one of the local eateries nearby and enjoy the sun and sand or cop a squat on the grass for a picnic.  Follow this up with a quick or not so quick swim or frolic in the ocean.  Great place to take the kids on a sunny day!
author: Michele P.

description:
Aquatic Park offers a great view of the ocean and bridge, but if you're looking for a beach, this is not the place.

The ocean winds are so strong that you're basically constantly being attacked by the sand. No good for your body.

Aside from that, Aquatic Park's location is a great place to just relax and chill. It's a walk from Fisherman's Wharf and Ghiradhelli, and you can't go wrong in those two places!

Picture: http://bit.ly/hmcQwl
author: Katty K.

description:
This is a good place to swim, it's not rocky, but the water is dark as it is the bay. You WILL be surrounded by a couple seals here and there, but none have ever bothered me. It is very still in the mornings - my favorite time to swim is early a.m. on the weekends. From one end (white buoy) to the other is 250 meters, which is an easy way to measure your distance when training for a race or just timing your progress.

Take note of the tides - we left our sandals and stuff on the steps after work one day, around 6 p.m., and luckily spotted them starting to float as the waves crept up to shore or we would've lost everything! Keep your "stuff" in the grandstands when you swim! Also note - NO lifeguard on duty. I've never swam alone here and never will. Buddy system is best!

Of the places I've swam in the bay area, I prefer this "park" to McNear beach in Marin and to all of the swim areas in Redwood City, which are full of bird poop and smell awful.
author: Stephanie N.

description: Awesome little spot. Muni pier and  Ghirardelli is close by. If your the outdoors and relax type you'll like this place. Grab a bite, sit their and just chill.
author: T C.

description:
I've always loved this little area of San Francisco.  In college I used to ditch some of my classes and come here for the day to sit and think.  I've spent some great days and not so great days lounging around this area.

Most recently my wife and I came here to reflect after our dog died.  We brought our other dog and just watched the water.  It was nice and peaceful.  Even the guy peeing in the bushes couldn't phase us that day.

It's not like this place is a secret, but it feels like it sometimes.
author: Nick M.

description: Swimmers, runners, bikers, tourists, and kids. What a fun place to watch people. A thug yelling and cussing on his phone, little kids giggling, and puffing of the runners. You get it all along with a view of the water and a little sun. Relaxing. Good stuff. Bring a wetsuit ;-)
author: Graham Y.

description: I love aquatic park. absolutely lovely spot to swim at! gorgeous views of sf and safe waters to swim although quite cold! One of my favourite place to practice open water swimming at, a good place to start, adjust to the temperature, be one with nature, and prepare for swimming to Alcatraz!  It's ocean temperature, but tiny waves, and generally little, if any current. Not good for noisy children, great for proper swimmers and trainers!
author: Julian I.

description: On a great sunny day, there aren't too many places better than Aquatic Park.  Lively, a lot to do in the neighborhood, and great views of the city.
author: Mel G.

description:
This might be the coolest place in Fisherman's Wharf. 

Did a swim race from Alcatraz that ended here. Personally, I hate swimming, I only do it because it's part of a triathlon. However, looking back on the race, this was the first time I ever truly enjoyed swimming. Scenic views out and a protected environment to practice in? You've got it made

If you've never tried swimming in open water I would highly recommend it, the water *honestly* isn't that cold, you get used to it surprisingly fast.

Even if you don't swim, it's still cool to either walk on the piers or sit on the bleachers and watch everyone else. People timidly approaching the water, jumping in the water then running out. Watching people do laps. 

You've got a cool little place here
author: Alex M.

description:
aquatic park is absolutely one of my favorite places to swim.    i first swam here back in 2001 when i was training for my first open water swim from angel island to tiburon.  now i train here whenever i'm preparing for alcatraz swims or any other open water events in the bay.  although it's part of the bay, it's enclosed enough that it seldom gets choppy.  street parking may be a bit difficult on the weekends but not if you come early.  there is a shower so you can rinse the salt water off.  the water temp varies between 52 to 62 degrees throughout the year. 

it's best to come with a friend so he or she can watch your valuables while you swim since there are no locker facilities.  another option is to pay the daily use fees for either dolphin club or south end rowing club which are adjacent to aquatic park.  i usually leave my belongings in my car and put my key fob in a waterproof baggy and tucking that in my wetsuit....yes, i use a wetsuit (hold the snickers).  

it's a beautiful part of san francisco and where else can you swim safely with the golden gate and acaltraz in the back ground?
author: Leon C.

description: A lovely place to take a break if you're down in that neck of the city. Not the best views in the city, but how lucky are we that a place like Aquatic Park is only A-OK? There are many cities where this would be the best place to hang out.
author: Megan S.

description:
I love Aquatic Park.  It is mine and my best friend's go to spot.  I have spent many days and nights out there.  It's fun just to hang out there and meet new people.  In fact, you meet the most interesting people there.

I was there one day about two years ago and my best friend and I run into this lady tending to some plants and sitting next to her was her cat and a skunk.  The skunk spotted us and ran off.  The lady said, "Good bye, Bradley!"... I thought... Did she really just have a wild pet skunk?  And she named it Bradley?!!?

Hahah good times!
author: Eleanor L.

description:
Approximately 2.5 laps open water swimming at Aquatic Park equals one mile and is one of Bay Area's most excellent of places to swim with unreal views of the Bay & Golden Gate Bridge, protected from water crafts and safe distance from beach, heated only by sun (so very ecological) and a great way to make new friends - both human and non-human. 

On the improvement side of things the underwater visibility is somewhat limited and nature's heating system sometimes surprises you, especially winters but free shower at the very end of Jefferson St is nice extra and as a bonus you may end up in many tourists private vacation/photo albums. Go take a swim!
author: Jari S.

description: I don't know what it is about this artificial beach that I love so much! Maybe it's because the waves are mild so they don't freak me out. Maybe it's because the Bay water is not as cold as the ocean water so I can actually dip my toes in the water. Maybe it's because it's nostalgic when I recall memories of my childhood, of flipping over rocks to find tiny crabs. Maybe it's because I love being able to lay out on grass, staying clean from grains of sand while still being able to watch the waters. Maybe it's because I love having so many options for food when I'm done with my day of lying around. Although this is a tourist site, there's not as much traffic as you'd think. There are plenty of places to lay out your picnic and even some secluded spots. The area is small, but there's so much beauty to take in.
author: Helen L.

description: BEAUTIFUL VIEWS! =] cant wait to watch fireworks here
author: Andrew V.

description: Who can say anything bad about Aquatic Park? I love this place. I never swam here but I do see people swimming laps and I give them credit for doing that. I love coming here at Sunset (when it's not foggy) and you can see the golden gate bridge off to the left and alcatraz. I can't even describe the feeling that you get when you are there. The sound of the water washing up on the sand, the flash of light from Alcatraz skimming across your face it's a feeling I can't describe. Again this is another reason why I love living in San Francisco. I can experience this as much as I want. No matter what time of the day it is, Aquatic Park will definitely capture your heart.
author: Philip O.

description: I didn't even know this was named anything until I pulled out my phone and "Aquatic park" showed for where I was.  The views here are beautiful and if you're a tourist, you can blow off a few hours just gazing.  There are swimmers here, noted by the pair of woman's shoes sitting on the closest step to the water and a bunch of guys coming out in swim suits.  I'd likely be there right now if I were in the city, but i'm back home so, next time!
author: Jamarcus T.

description:
I finally did it, I swam in Aquatic Park!!!!!  So getting in is the initial shock, so COLD!   I waited till my heart rate went down before I started to swim out.  The water visibility wasn't clear at all, so I swam with my head up and switched off to backstroke.  It was so beautiful to stare up at the sky and watch the clouds go by.  I love to be in the water so this was a big treat for me.  I recommend for those who are amateur swimmers and who are not tri-athletes, to bring along a pair of good fins, so you can actually get somewhere.  Have fun in San Francisco

If you don't feel like getting in the water, the beach is cute to lay on and read a book.  Or if you want to get your feet wet you can wade in the water to the point of your comfort.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Even with all the recent renovation and construction going on, this is still one of the more beautiful and yet lesser visited and under-utilized  parts of the city.  I've seen some downright stunning sunsets here and the vista of the bay with the Balclutha and other vintage ships in the foreground make it all seem rather timeless.

Those new concrete bleachers have been taking forever (is it two years yet?), but they're sure starting to look nicely done.  This will be a great place to spend some time or have a picnic lunch with that special someone.

With all the new wine bars in the area, this walkway is even more desirable for a nice romantic walk along the waterfront.  Aquatic Park is so great that even the wild parrots of Telegraph Hill have started to regularly flock there.  With their numbers growing, this has become the third point of their triangle between Telegraph Hill, Embarcadero, and now Aquatic Park.  I love those little guys!   This is a great place for locals and tourists alike...birds too.  Five stars!
author: Roy N.

description: R.I.P. Grandpa. Enjoy the view. I'll miss you.
author: Jason B.

description: Calming place to chill, relax and see the gorgeous view of the GG Bridge & hear the waves especially at night. Perfect for taking strolls and your kids to roam around free. Just be careful with people riding their bikes- there's actually a lane for that and they appear outta nowhere sometimes. Only downside is people smokin weed and it's not good for kids. That's pretty much it...
author: Jade D.

description:
I went to Aquatic Park last weekend to practice my open water swimming leg for my upcoming triathlons and absolutetly love it!  Open water swimming in the bay cannot be beat.  Yes, the water is freezing cold, but that does not stop swimmers from diving in without a wetsuit (I used my wetsuit). There were probably 6 swimmers in the water with me so I was not alone in these deep ocean waters.  Ill be sure to frequent this place to keep on practicing.

On top of that, this place is right in front of Ghiradelli square so you can pass by and grab some hot chocolate in one of their cafes after your super cold open water swim.
author: John A.

description:
The is the best place to practice your open water swimming.  Why?  Because the bottom of the bay at Aquatic Park is sandy, and not slimy. 

After a disgusting swim at Treasure Island, I was expecting the worst and was so pleasantly surprised at the sandy bottom.

One lap is about 1/3 of a mile (a total rumor). Go on a calm day and enjoy the gentle rocking of the tide. 

For those of you who don't want to swim alone, check out swimart (http://www.swim-art.com/), they have open water swimming programs at Aquatic Park.
author: Krissy M.

description:
5 minutes in and I was a meat popsicle!  I had to get out and run a few more laps before jumping back in.  Not sure of the exact temperature of the water.  The view is great swimming out to to the northeast side.

Parking was easy & great silhouette views of the city as the sun rises over the horizon on the east.
author: Victor V.

description:
My friends and I packed up our eco friendly cooler with all the essentials. You know, wine, beer, cheese, chips....the makings for a good 4th of July party. The best part was seeing the skateboarding dog. So flippin cute! I need to get me one of those!

Then the show started and it was like we were all 5 years old again. Eyes wide open and smiles for miles. The fog didn't hinder the show one bit! I'm so happy we found this perfect 4th of July fireworks viewing spot!
author: Casi C.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco. It is one place that you must give a try. Sure, it definitely gets its share of tourists wandering over, but I still love it. It's great for swimming, running and just sitting and taking in the beautiful views of the Bay and the Golden Gate. This is one of those places that I could spend hours. For some reason coming here always makes me (even more) happy that I live in SF.

I live up the street so I come often.
author: Anita B.

description: Start of US Half Marathon on Nov. 4, 2012.  A race that I will run in.  This will be my 7th 1/2 marathon race in 2 years.  This park has a grand stand that faces the little cove that is enclosed by VanNess Pier.  The pier act as barrier from the waves that comes from the SF Bay so the cove is a haven for swimmers.  It is a public park and swimming is a popular activity in the cove.  On land, it is a beautiful part of a run along the waterfront that starts from AT&T Park all the way to Crissy Field.  This part of route is one of my favorites as it affords you the view of the bay as you run along the concrete pavement next to the beach towards the direction of VanNess pier.  This is also the flat approach to the hill that goes through Fort Mason and just past VanNess pier.  The hill overlooks Fort Mason, the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.  This park is my chosen destination to end my long runs along the waterfront because of it's close proximity to Ghirardelli Ice Cream parlor where I indulge in some "recovery" treats.
author: Bob S.

description: I love Aquatic Park.  Whether I'm running through it as part of the Bridge to Bridge run, swimming laps in the cold water, admiring the Maritime Museum, catching 4th of July fireworks, looking down at it from Ghirardelli Square or the Buena Vista Cafe.  I just love it.
author: Corey V.

description: I had my first swim in Aquatic Park over the weekend - wetsuit ready and on! Did my three laps and called it a day. Perfect weather out and the water was not too chilly in the wetsuit. I can imagine during the winter months it being very cold! I'll be back  - need to keep training for my upcoming triathlon!
author: Julie F.

description: Great spot for people watching.  You get to see a mixture of tourists and locals.
author: Irene T.

description:
Being the typically "on-time" homeboy that I am, I got to last nights dinner rendezvous about 45 minutes early and decided, with my better judgment, not to sit at the bar and wait (and drink), but rather, to enjoy the surrounding area.

The night was somewhat warm, the wind still and the end of Van Ness alluringly quiet.  My eyes were burning from the days computer work (the last 1.5 hours devoted to Patricia P.  ;)  ) so finding a relaxing spot to cop a squat was my main priority.

Alas, my paradise!!!!  Aquatic Park!!!!  I found a bench, sat alone and had a very enjoyable time watching people swim, jog, bike, urinate (yes, there was ONE bum, didn't enjoy that too much) and enjoy the beautiful views of Alcatraz. Angel Island, the Oakland Hills and the meandering ferries powering across the bay.  Amidst my decompression, I realized that I had been here, for the first time, as a child of 7 with my great aunt and uncle (who are still alive at 92!!!).  My strongest memory of the day, I recalled, was one of itching (because of the sand fleas) and being very cold (swimming in the summer in the SF bay???  See Mark Twain for details).

After my 45 minutes, I felt completely rejuvinated and ready to join my cohorts in a night of drink and food, which, I did with an alarmingly high degree of success.

Love it, dig it, I wanna be buried there (when I die, smart ass!)
author: Johnny L.

description:
I love this spot.. it can get pretty crowded and parking can be hard to find if all the parking... but is pretty much ocean swimming.

On a nice day..expect crowds.
author: Roger A.

description:
Swimming in the Bay is an addiction, and Aquatic Park really delivers. Mild currents, cold water, and  nice place to  dry off and watch  boats go by when it's all over.

Swim without a wet suit if you dare. It's an acquired skill but a lot of fun. What I love most about this place is the diversity of those who use it: tourists and families dipping their toes in, 20-30 something after-work triathletes, 70 year olds who've been swimming there for 40 years and the occasional sea lion.

I've never had a problem leaving my stuff on the beach, most folks seem to be tourists, or there to swim or people-watch.
author: Dana S.

description:
When I moved to San Francisco, I had no idea that I would be living so close to the water.  But I am one of the lucky people that have Aquatic park within walking distance (less than 20 minutes).  
Aquatic Park to me is a couple of things.
It's a place to sit and read the paper.  
Drink a cup of coffee while watching tourists.
Go for weekly swims.  The water is cold but you honestly get used to it.
I like it because I can feel like a tourist checking out the area but yet I can always find some space to relax whether it be on the grass, the big stone steps, or on the beach.  
Usually you'll find me in the water though if I'm in the area.
author: John B.

description:
Now I can proudly say that I am one of those damn fools that swims at Aquatic Park early on a fine Sunday morn.  Four hours sleep only?  No problem.  Nothing wakes you like sixty-something degree water... better than coffee.

The first time I swam here, involutarily I couldn't get myself to put my face in the frigid water.  And I was screaming like a little girl... "aaahhhhh, ahhhhhh, shix its cold, aaahhhh."  And my buddy was there yelling, "Get your head in the water, get your head in the water!!!"

But today was my 2nd time.  I swam with a bunch of folks from the local tri club that I never met before.  Breathe deeply I told myself, warm up them shoulders, but most of all, DON'T SCREAM LIKE A LITTLE GIRL!  

Whew, wasn't as bad as the first time.  I guess it never is.
author: Bryan K.

description: Great park with an awesome view. Get your Ghiradelli sundae and come enjoy it on the grass.
author: Sean M.

description:
Best place to train for open water swimming events!

Yes, the water is cold.  Yes, it may be dirty (but probably not as polluted as the air we breathe).  Yes, if you jump in tourists are likely to gape and take pictures.  Yes, that homeless man is trying to sneak a peak while you change under a towel.  All this aside, you will never have an adrenaline rush like swimming in the bay.  You will never see the sunset under the Golden Gate Bridge in quite the same way.  You will hate the first 5 minutes and then rejoice in the fact that you are the master of the bay!  Rock on, Aquatic Park, rock on!!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Review for swimming in the park:

+2 for no one stealing my shoes and clothes, which I left on the cement bleachers while I swam
+2 for not being as cold as I'd expected, and being perfectly bearable (in September, on a cloudy day) in just a swimsuit
+1 for swimming in an open body of water!

-1 for a wave hitting me in the face and going up my nose
author: V O.

description: I have a love hate relationship with this place. I think most people who swim here do.  So far, it's the best place I've found for open water swimming in the city. It's a great place to go to watch the sun rise. The boats, outer wall protection and occasional seal make it a fun place to swim. Sometimes in the summer you even feel like a creature of nature due to the tourists taking pictures of you and coming over to ask you . . isn't it cold? . . . it's 59 degrees on a good day but drops to around 53 in the colder months.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Once upon a time, a girl from the deep South moved to SF out of desperation.  By sheer luck and circumstance, she ended up living in an apartment neighboring Aquatic Park.  Like a miracle, her life turned upside down.  She fell in love with SF while sitting on the ampitheatre steps, drinking a mocha from Ghirardelli and watching the fog roll in.

If you haven't guessed it already,  the girl was me.  I no longer live on the hill behind Ghirardelli, but I remember the wonderful sunrises, sunsets and jogs that I enjoyed in that neighborhood.
author: Hiromi N.

description: This is THE place to swim in or around San Francisco (both figuratively and literally).  Ignore the seals and they will leave you alone.
author: Jeremy N.

description:
When it's nice it's great but when the weather is gray and cold I'd rather stay far away.
All the swimmers that you see are crazy!
The docks are cool!
and Hooters is near by so I can run off to work real quick
author: Kim S.

description:
Fun fun in the sun!

A few pre-reqs I have for parks:
- Flat areas where you can play catch, preferably with few pebbles and lots of green grass
- Restrooms please
- Few bugs
- Lots of cute dogs and kids running around!

Check, check, check, and check! 

Played with friends on the green, green side of the Aquatic Park (the part sorta far from the aqua part of the park), and had a blast! It's the part of San Francisco that you just can't help but fall in love with - with views of the Golden Gate bridge, the water, and the sweet hum of the wind blowing through your hair (can't you just picture it now).

Also, with Fort Mason nearby, it's easier to find parking than you think (the 4 hr kind - lucky we got!) 

More fun fun in the sun for me!
author: Diana L.

description:
Yeah, I'm not the biggest fan.  It's cool and all.  I guess.  I mean, I would spend lots of time here if I lived closer, especially if I had lived closer when I was in high school.  But much like the stuff I actually did do in high school, I don't understand why other people would be interested in it.

So I like it, but you probably won't.  Unless you like it because other people like it.  Or because you're supposed to like it.

I guess.
author: John S.

description: Aquatic Park is among the beat places on earth! Great for people watching. But most if all, one of the most relaxing places to swim open water. Great place!!!
author: Andrew M.

description:
So back when I was in high school, this was the place to hang out with your friends late night after going to the Ghirardelli fountain. Now, 10 years later, it's my normal open water swim spot.

Catch this place on a sunny day, and the view of the Bay is astonishing. Is it touristy, absolutely. But it's also on of the best visual representations/justifications of why the hell we pay so much to live here!
author: Douglas L.

description:
I live across the street, and I never tire of this place. From the view of the Balclutha to the yearly fireworks show, this is one of the most picturesque public areas in this very picturesque of towns. There's always something new to see in the fog and the sun-dappled waters.

I have yet to take the plunge and buy a wetsuit to go swimming, but the triathlete crazies are here every day, and they swear by it.

When the nights are cold and clear, you can see the lighthouse with Alcatraz. Perfect, quiet spot to enjoy a Scotch.

Edit on 7/16:
I bought the wetsuit, and I went swimming this morning. FUCK! It's as cold as it looks!
author: Derek C.

description: Perfect viewing to watch the Fleet Week Air Show. There is stadium style seating next to the Maritime Museum, or you can set up on the grass. In the "stadium" bring something soft to sit on, because it will start to get uncomfortable sitting on concrete. There's even room to bring pop up chairs. Get their early to get prime seats, other wise it will get crowded once the air show begins.
author: Kristine G.

description:
Did you know if you yell from the stairway/seating arena area the swimmers can hear you!!! 

I was on a run with my roommate. She told me her sister was swimming at the aquatic park while we were running along the beach's path... I walk up the stairway looking over the water... We spotted two heads bobbing and swaying from the waves... I yell, ERICAAaaa!!! I see an arm come up from the water waving to us from what seems to be a mile away. Soon after she emerges from the waters shore to greet us with a smile and the smell of kelp. Now... I have to ask, what is rewarding about swimming in the shark infested waters??? :)

For the most part I give anyone who swims these water major brownie points. I am proud of the swimmers!!!

I enjoy watching the waters from these steps and will continue to visit.
author: Dee C.

description: From the point of view of a spectator, this is a nice sopt.  I came out here to watch my boyfriend and his brother practice for the Alcatraz Swim.  There are lots of steps to sit on, and the best part is, Ghirradelli Square is not very far, is you want to go get some great hot chocolate while you wait!  The scenery around is enjoyable, and not far is 4 hour parking!! Love it!
author: Sheena J.

description: Beautiful location to people watch and see the beautiful bay.  You can see Alcatraz from many of the benches in Aquatic Park.  You can walk to the touristy restaurants and stores nearby.  Great place to bring out of town guests or just to hang outside when the weather is nice.  Parking is a bitch but I got lucky last time so it can be done.  There's a museum here too.  Never been in it but might be of interest to people.  I think it has history about ships, etc.
author: Caroline O.

description:
I useta live a few blocks up the hill from here and made it part of the morning dog-walking route.  Probably the most peaceful place in all of Fisherman's Wharf, especially in the morning before 10 a.m.  

Nicely kept green grass and fragrant flowers, friendly resident homeless people, cool rock sculptor who makes amazing gravity-defying towers of rocks on the western side of the beach.  The water is tolerable in warm weather, but the beach gets packed with families running in and out of the water.

Occasional sea lions (or are they seals?) in the swimming lanes!

Jack, one of the Park Service Groundskeepers, always has dog cookies in his mini-truck.

Lack of stars for not letting dogs on the beach, it's crowded at times, and sometimes it just smells (the water and sometimes skunks who live in the park).
author: Angela C.

description:
First place I dove into the San Francisco bay.  Well, maybe "dove" is too strong (dived?)... it was more like, waded.  But I waded in, and swam around, once a year, for several years... before I wised up and found a proper indoor pool.

However, bay bathing aside, Aquatic park is pretty cool.  The Hyde Street cable car turnaround gives an excellent view of the part from the east end, and the park includes a great area to sit and watch street theater, or you can wander down to the west end and visit the Maritime Museum.  Or watch the early morning exercise classes as they do pushups and run up and down the stairs as dawn breaks over the bay.  

Good times....
author: H.A. ..

description:
It's a beautiful location to stroll by or just chill out on the beach, people watching or just enjoying the sun. People do swim here in the very icy cold water but guess they are used to it or at least in their wet suits! :)

Great place to watch July 4 fireworks altho be prepared to be fighting for your personal space with 100000000 others! Go early and secure a spot! :)
author: Yan M.

description:
Such a beautiful spot - nice to look at, walk around a bit or relax with a sandwich and a book if the weather is nice...

If you're a tourist or homeless you'll love this place!
author: Quartknee K.

description: i am really happy that on sunny days people flock to dolores park or fort mason because it leaves this little known treasure all to myself!!!!! it has great views, a beach, and bocce ball! awesome. so its by a tourist area but its a total gem. you can either sit on the grass, stairs, or beach and just enjoy how senic this city really is. i suggest taking a nice little picnic and music and chill out on this place. its fun to watch the ships and crazy swimmers on a beautiful day. i love that i have found my second favorite place to go to clear my mind and remember that life is beautiful. one day ill try to get in on a pick up game of bocce ball.
author: Ashley H.

description:
If you've got balls or wanna test it, swim here. 
Also a great spot to come with the paper & a cup of coffee from  La Boulangerie de Polk (Polk & Green), make sure its not too windy though.
Great place to start a walk- go up and over the hill and you're at Fort Mason, such a great place...on a nice day. 
Sometimes there's some not so awesome dudes around and there's a few more tourists that you'd like, kinda cute in a way.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
I finally did it! I've been wanting to try open water swimming for a long time now and today I mustered up the courage to go to Aquatic Park to swim! I almost hate to say it because I would not want to see it get crowded with swimmers but it's not that bad. It's actually kind of a neat and very exhilarating feeling you get from swimming in the cold water without a wetsuit.
 I waded in at first until the water was almost up to my waist and then dove in. My first thought was f**k it's cold!! But then after a few minutes or less, not that long really I got sort of used to it. The temperature was even easier to deal with than the mild chop that was on the water today. 
 I've been practicing alternate breathing (being able to take a breath from either side) while swimming laps in the pool to get myself ready for open water but it's not the same. You have to be able to time your breathing with the waves and I was having trouble doing so. I ended up getting a lot of water in my mouth. I tried swimming mostly backstroke but since I'd seen a jellyfish (it's rare to see just one) and I didn't want to hit any I kind of did a  backstroke and turn to look ahead and then back again which I'm sure looked funny from shore to the more experienced swimmers. 
 Hey, I'm new at this and I don't mind if it looks obvious. I'm out here doing it and I will be back. I've heard that it takes three times before you're completely comfortable and I'm looking forward to getting those first three out of the way.
author: Steve N.

description:
Update: 12/15/2007: I went back into the cove for the first time since the oil spill and did one lap and had to get out! It was shivers me timbers in the cove and I couldn't last more than one lap even in my full garb - wetsuit, neoprene swim cap, gloves and booties! My Ironman training should not be this tough but MAN it is cold in the cove during Decembers and Januarys so I hear! Maybe I just need to run and warm up first before I jump in!

No sign of Nibbles the harbor seal. I think he is gone for wintertime and will return in the spring to terrorize everyone by the left flag again!
======
Update: 11/9/2007: The cove is closed indefinitely because of the cargo ship that collided with the second tower of the Bay Bridge and leaked 58,000 gallons of bunker oil. I am without an open water swim place in SF for a LONG time....  :(
======
My Vineman Half Ironman swim training begins here in the chilly waters at Aquatic Park!
author: Will C.

description: This little beach is a perfect spot to go just to relax. Mornings and late nights are the best times to go where there really is only a few, if that, people on the beach. Perfect viewing spot for events such as 4th of july fireworks and the blue angels air shows. But when i say perfect, i mean in terms of how close you are to the view. You have to get there early on big events because it gets rather packed.
author: Shawna S.

description:
I am one of the crazy people who swims at aquatic park sans wetsuit (when I get a chance).  I am that girl. 
I love aquatic park. I live in Japantown and my early morning walks (yeah, I'm also that kind of crazy who WALKS to aquatic park from J-Town for a swim and then walks home again) to aquatic park are the stuff of dreams as far as I'm concerned. Cutting through the actual park area directly to the left of the sandy beach affords breathtaking views of the water. The pier is a delight to sit at the end of, especially on days when no one else is around. When it's too cold to take a dip, sipping coffee on the pier and walking barefoot in the sand is a fine substitute. On a good day, I have the pleasure of having the whole pier and beach to myself, but you have to get there pretty early for that. The maritime museum rounds out the experience for folks who haven't been before but it's closed til next year at least. If you haven't been, I highly recommend a visit.
author: Autumn K.

description: Charming and historic--walking along the beach/park and checking out the boats is super fun--like museums on water.
author: Jaynel G.

description:
got this great picture that my sister took of me and my cousins....looks like one of those black n white emo pics....looking off into the distance

not to mention it's one of those places I can always seem to find parking when everyone and their mama is up in the wharf area. 

on another note there are skunks...watch out
author: John-Michael C.

description: Beautiful place to visit.  I didn't even know this place was here until I stumbled upon it one day.  Great during a nice warm day.
author: Robin L.

description:
This is one of the places that make SF so special, especially for us crazy swimmers/triathletes.  This is a protected harbor with a large area set aside for swimmers to swim safely (use a wetsuit and multiple caps until you get used to the frigid bay water!).  I've swum all the way out to the bay, past the docks, and as long as you keep your eyes open, it's very safe, since only a few sailboats come in there to dock.  This is the best place I know of for open-water swimming in SF.
    There's great scenery everywhere - Ghiardelli and SF city behind you (not to mention hot chicks jogging around), Angel and Alcatraz Islands, Marin out in front of you.  Some huge sailing vessel to your right as you enter the water (I forget Her name), there's usually other swimmers around - fun chatting with them as your face numbs up.
   The only negative is parking can be a bitch - forget weekends after 10 am and nice weekday afternoons.  Otherwise you can usually find  a spot close by in a four-hour spot right there.
author: Greg R.

description: With the summer weather upon us.. I was talked into going for a swim at Aquatic park.  Never one to be a big fan of lane pool swimming, its hard to compare that to swimming in the open water with views of the bay and alcatraz.  Not being the greatest of swimmers, I went with I friend of mine who swims competively.  Having no hangups on getting schooled by a women, I figured with her around there was no way I was gonna go under, haha.  Even with a wet suit, the water was cold, but after a few minutes my body got used to it.  After taking a couple laps around the bouys, it what could be described as horrible form.. she swims like a mermaid, I was exhausted.  Probably putting this on the backburner for now.
author: Frank K.

description: Best beach in SF!  My 4 years old's favorite beach to go to during the summer.  We always go in the mornings and then have a nice lunch at the pier or Ghirardelli Square.  Love this place!
author: Chris R.

description: Nice scenery and alot of people.  The smell of algae and the bright warm sun are nice.  When its windy don't stay for long time.  You can do laps here in the water.  I advise not to drink the water or put in mouth because the water is not clean.  Must shower after swimming.  Nice place to sunbath because large area to lay but bath only if the sun is out and is a warm day.  Watch out for the seagulls they might poop on you.
author: John F.

description: The water is cold.  i don't know how those guys swim here without a wetsuit.  There is a roped off area where you can swim around.  The water is freezing.  Wear a long sleeved wetsuit.  When you are swimming you will catch some algae.  The water tastes gross.  I really don't like swimming here.  A lot of people practice for open water here and I have to give you guys some props.  The water is cold.  Did I say the water was freezing?  Yes.  The water.  It is cold.
author: apple r.

description: Yes, it's cold, but with proper gear you're all set.  I love starting off my day here, I was intimidated by it for about a year and then finally dragged a friend with me to brave it and haven't stopped since.  It's so much better than a cramped pool with floaty nasty stuff, having to flip turn every 2 seconds. At least in the ocean things are diluted out- at least that's my theory.
author: courtney W.

description: A charming little resting place after a nice stroll from the Embarcadero/Pier 39. It doesn't hurt that the Ghirardelli chocolate factory is a short walk up from here either. One can sit or lay here for hours and enjoy the cool breeze. It's a wonderful little spot any one in San Francisco should stop by.
author: Lauren L.

description:
A great place if you are nutty enough to enjoy a cool dip in the bay!

Buddy dragged me down here one morning to take part in his ritual morning swim before work. Brilliant idea to get in your exercise in the morning and no need for coffee as swimming here is the equivalent of intravenous Peet's. 

The aquatic park is protected on the majority of sides by docks/piers, and there are no boats to worry about. So you are free to swim. A very cool looking replica ship in the far corner of the park too. 

Beautiful scenery everywhere, Alcatraz, Ghiradelli square and the two docks for the old time rowing/swim clubs. Parking is easy too, so you only have a quick run back to the car to crank up the heat.

Perfect place to practice open water swimming it seems as you can adjust to the vocal impairing, stunning cold of the water.
author: David B.

description: I swim and therefore, this has to get a review. I've been swimming here since 2001 and it's always fun. I've seen shops come and go along Ocean Ave (miss the "deep dish" pizza place the most) but the water's always there. As you can see in many other reviews - there's something special about getting in frigid water that shocks your system to numbness... I couldn't get that in a nice closed area if it weren't for AP. Love it. Also, surprisingly safe to leave your stuff out when you swim - I've yet to have anyone take my stuff that I stash when I'm out in the water - I may have just cursed myself but no worries...
author: Mark J.

description: Running here is so much fun!  Start at the Marina Green and head to Aquatic Park.  Believe it or not, it's actually fun to keep going and run through Fisherman's Wharf and on to Pier 39.  I know, sounds a bit sadistic, but dodging tourists can actually be a great workout.  Give it a try!
author: Christina N.

description: I have no plans to test the water here, as the hill leading up to Fort Mason is enough suffering for me. Go here on the weekends and see how many times you can sprint up this hill and then walk back down. If you do more than 2, you never need to workout again.
author: Brock D.

description: A wading area without rip tides! Beautiful mornings and beautiful views to enjoy. Watch the Dolphin Club swimmers do their laps in the Bay.
author: miriam b.

description: This place is perfectly situated between Ghirardelli Square and Fisherman's Wharf. The grassy field is second to none on a sunny day and the atmosphere is incredible.
author: Kyle S.

description: This is the place to swim and get in shape. I've done the whole swimming pool at gyms thing, and lets face it, we sure have some pesky residents that don't like to share swimming lanes, or like to show off how much better of a swimmer they are than you, and of course, maybe this has a little to do with my own insecurities, however, at Aquatic Park you get in, and for the first 30 seconds there is a period of whether you just might die, but if you pass that 30 seconds, your free to swim in open waters, no one to bother you or get annoyed with you, I would however like a swimming partner that way if we get bit by a sea lion or attacked by a shark, I at least have a 50% chance of getting away, but for right now I'll settle with swimming down there about twice a week to get myself back into dating shape, of course that doesn't neccessarily mean I'll find a date!! Also, for you daring San Franciscans that like to actually be spontaneous and have fun, aquatic park is perfect for a  after bar dip with your friends, done it multiple times and it's always DOPE, however, a tad bit cold after you get out since you can't use the showers in the facilities after hours, rush home and take a warm shower.
author: John A.

description: People who get into this water without a wetsuit are certifiably insane.  I'm sure Peter M. could come up with some psychobabblicious theory about how the folks who get into this freezing cold water had parents who didn't let them have a tricycle or something.  So, my CRAZY lil sister sacrificed her wetsuit and went in bare-skinned so that I would swim with her.  After I got over a mild asthma attack caused by these arctic waters, I put my head down and struggled agains the wetsuit and tide to do a whopping two laps, which took a half an hour.  My face was numb and I couldn't really talk.  My feet were frozen and I couldn't really walk.  I half staggered, half stumbled up the sand to the hose in front of the South End Rowing club to rinse off.  Sister didn't seem to understand that the water is FREEZING cold.  She just kinda stood under the just-as-cold shower and rinsed off.  She's bonkers.  I made a run for the hot showers and sauna.  Most people that swim down there regularly would call me a wimp and weeny for wearing a wetsuit, but frankly, I call it common sense and sanity.  I had a tricycle.  I couldn't be happier to have a natural resource like this at the tips of our fingers and even though I've only taken advantage of it twice, I'm glad it's there to deflate my ego when I feel like I'm improving in the pool.
author: ellyk E.

description: Oh Beautiful Morning. So exhilarating, and where else can you swim and watch the sun rise?
author: Cbr A.

description: this is a short walk from lombard street (crooked street) or the fisherman's wharf.  it's a nice place to stroll around.  i didn't go for dip, but there were swimmers (in march).  you can walk out to the municipal pier, where you can see alcatraz and the golden gate bridge across the water.  then walk up to fort mason which is another nice place for a stroll on a clear day.
author: Immer E.

description: This place is one of the many reasons San Fran is a great city, especially for anyone who likes outdoor activities.  It is a protected cove by Fort Mason with a line of buoys about .17 miles long, perfect for open water lap swimming.  You can swim the buoys or along the piers.  Beautiful views of Ghiradelli Square and the Balcutha. .Yes, the water is frigid, but after about 2 minutes its not too bad at all (I usually wear neoprene, which helps, but many--- most it seems-- -go bareback, god bless them). . Swimming in the bay is to pool swimming what biking across the GG Bridge is to stationary biking at the Y.   In other words, it's WAY cooler (literally!). . It's like you become part of the city while you swim in thos chilly waters.  Of note, the Hyde Street Pier, Fort Mason, and Ghiradelli Square (all of which are adjacent to Aquatic Park) are all pretty cool too.  Finally, rounding out the coolness is the fact that the marina green, crissy field, and fort point are all jog-able (and what a scenic, engergizing jog it is) from aquatic park.
author: JAW J.

description: this is a hidden san francisco gem! a great place to bring your lunch and unwind and relax. i've done it a few times just make sure to bring a jacket since it gets a little windy and cold. a great place to check out is hyde street pier close by.
author: Lan P.

description: Another must-see location I take out-of-town visitors to.  I love watching all the *insane* people swimming in the cold water there.
author: iii i.
